'My mother carried me on her back, under fire': Life around Haiti's gang-squeezed capital
subhed: Haiti has 1.4 million displaced people who are victims of the criminal gangs that control much of the greater Port-au-Prince area. Recently, law enforcement and militias have appeared to halt their progress.

subhed: The former French president spent three weeks in detention in La Santé prison this autumn. His book will be released on December 10, his publisher announced on Friday.

title: Sex, lies and bicycles: Espionage scandal rocks Denmark
subhed: The head of the Danish intelligence services allegedly provided false information to political leaders in the Kingdom of Denmark to justify placing the director of military intelligence under surveillance for nearly a year.

title: Aya Nakamura's 'Destinée': Singer's fifth album brims with renewed energy

title: 'He looked me up and down': Hostesses, flight attendants and waitresses speak out about everyday sexualization
subhed: Crude jokes, inappropriate stares and overt flirting are commonplace for women in service jobs where physical appearance is paramount. Employees remain poorly protected from this sexualization, which can amount to harassment.

The 'everlasting peace' in Gaza promised by Trump is off to a troubled start
subhed: The US president described the UN Security Council's vote on phase II of his peace plan as the dawn 'a golden age for the Middle East.' But how can we separate this bluster from actual reality, asks Le Monde columnist Alain Frachon.

title: Nicolas Guillou, French ICC judge sanctioned by the US: 'You are effectively blacklisted by much of the world's banking system'
byline: Interview by Stéphanie Maupas (The Hague (Netherlands) correspondent)
subhed: Six judges and three prosecutors at the International Criminal Court have been sanctioned by the Trump administration. In an interview with Le Monde, Guillou discusses the impact of these measures on his work and daily life.

title: Inequality on the rise in France amid a staggering surge in income among the ultrarich
subhed: The wealthiest 0.1% of French people earn, on average, 167 times more than the quarter of households with the lowest incomes, according to France's National Institute of Statistics and Economic Studies. The gap has widened dramatically over the past 20 years, while reforms introduced by Emmanuel Macron have reduced the tax rate for the richest households.
